fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An adjunction F \dashv G between categories C and D entails the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a pair of functors F:C\leftrightarrows D:G, called the left and right adjoints;
a family of natural bijections D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd), called transposition;
a natural transformation 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } GF, called the unit;
a natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D, called the counit.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data relates as follows:

fr:ul.fr:li: the component c\xrightarrow {\eta _c}GFc of the unit is the transpose of the identity 1_{Fc};
the component FGd\xrightarrow {\epsilon _d}d of the counit is the transpose of the identity 1_{Gd};
the transposition of a map Fc\xrightarrow {f} d is the composite c\xrightarrow {\eta _c} GFc\xrightarrow {Gf} Gd;
the transposition of a map c\xrightarrow {g} Gd is the composite Fc\xrightarrow {Fg} FGd\xrightarrow {\epsilon _d} d;

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F: C\leftrightarrows D: G be a pair of opposing functors. Then the following are equivalent specifications of an adjunction:

fr:ul.fr:li: there exists a natural bijection D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd);
there exists a pair of natural transformations 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } GF and FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D satisfying the triangle identities;

there exists a natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D so that the formula for adjoint maps induces an isomorphism (-)^\sharp = C(c, Gd)\xrightarrow {F} D(Fc, FGd)\xrightarrow {(\epsilon _d)_*} D(Fc, d).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first implies the second via the triangle identities of the unit and counit.

fr:ul.fr:li: H\eta = \eta 'H, where \eta and \eta ' are the units of the adjunctions;
K\epsilon = \epsilon 'K, where \epsilon and \epsilon ' are the counits of the adjunctions;
transposition commutes with H and K.

fr:title.text: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the forwards direction, suppose that the isomorphisms are natural, and further that the left-hand square commutes; the case in which the right-hand square commutes is similar. By the naturality of the isomorphism in C, the transpose of kf^\sharp is (Gk) f^\flat , while by naturality in D, the transpose of (Fh)g^\sharp is hg^\flat . Since the maps are equal, their transposes must also be equal; this is commutativity of the square on the right.

fr:title.text: Adjoints are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Adjoints are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F and F' be left adjoints to G. Then there is a unique natural isomorphism \theta : F\cong F' commuting with the units and counits of the adjunctions.
Dually, right adjoints are also unique up to unique isomorphism commuting with the units and counits.
To show uniqueness, note that \theta _c is uniquely specified as the transpose of \eta '_c across the adjunction F\dashv G, but this relationship is required for commutativity with the units to hold.
There are composite bijections of hom-sets E(F'Fc, e)\cong D(Fc, G'E)\cong C(c, GG'e).

Let \eta and \epsilon be the unit and counits of the adjunction F\dashv G. We give a unit \eta ' and counit \epsilon ' witnessing the adjunction F_*\dashv G_*. Given a functor J\xrightarrow {H} C, the component H\xrightarrow {\eta '_H} GFH is the whiskered natural transformation \eta H. Given a functor J\xrightarrow {K} D, the component FGK\xrightarrow {\epsilon '_K} K is similarly \epsilon K.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a functor so that, for each object d\in D, there exists a cofree object Gd\in C, i.e. an object Gd\in C together with an isomorphism {D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd)} natural in D. Then there exists a unique extension of this assignment into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C, which is then necessarily right adjoint to F.
Dually, suppose that for each d\in D, there exists a free object Fd\in C. Then this data extends uniquely into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C which is necessarily left adjoint to F.

fr:title.text: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:title.text: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Right adjoints preserve limits. Dually, left adjoints preserve colimits.

Letting \Delta be the constant diagram functor, we have the following series of natural isomorphisms: \begin {aligned} C^J(\Delta c, GK) &\cong D^J(F\Delta c, K) &&\text {by (1)}\\\\ &\cong D^J(\Delta Fc, K) &&\text {by (2)}\\\\ &\cong D(Fc, \operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the definition of limits}\\\\ &\cong C(c, G\operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the adjunction}. \end {aligned} By definition of limits, this exhibits G\operatorname *{lim}_J K as a limit of GK.

Let D\xrightarrow {G} C be a continuous functor with locally small complete domain D. Suppose that D satisfies the solution set condition: for each object c in C, there exists a small family of maps c\xrightarrow {f_i} Gd_i in C such that any map c\xrightarrow {f} Gd factors through one of the f_i via the G-image of a map d_i\to d in D. Then G admits a left adjoint.

Let D\xrightarrow {G} C be a continuous functor with complete domain and locally small domain and codomain. Suppose that D has a small coseparating family and that every collection of subobjects x_\alpha \hookrightarrow x in D admits a meet, i.e. a limit. Then G has a left adjoint.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.
These are my notes on category theory.
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
Categories are ubiquitous in mathematics, as the following examples show.
The category of sets Set is the category whose objects are sets and whose morphisms are set-functions.
The category of relations Rel has sets as objects and relations as morphisms. Composition is given by existence, i.e. a (SR) c if and only if there is some b such that aRb and bRc.
The category of topological spaces Top is the category whose objects are topological spaces and whose morphisms are continuous functions.
The category of groups Grp is the category whose objects are groups and whose morphisms are homomorphisms.
We call these examples concrete. However, as the following examples show, not all categories look like this.
The empty category is the category with no objects and no morphisms.
The trivial category is the category with one object and only its identity morphism.

A preorder is a category P in which, for each pair of objects x and y, P(x, y) is either empty or a singleton. Explicitly, this means that it has a collection of elements (its objects) and a reflexive, transitive relation (inhabitance of hom-sets).
For any ordinal \alpha , there is a preorder whose objects are the smaller ordinals with the usual order.
A monoid can be thought of as a category with one object, whose morphisms are the elements of the monoid and whoses composition is the operation.
By the connection between monoids and categories, a group is a groupoid with one object.
A commutatitive diagram in a category C is a functor J\xrightarrow {D} C. The domain J is called the indexing category or the shape of the diagram.

A cone over a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C with apex c\in C is a natural transformation c\xrightarrow {\lambda } D, where c is the constant functor at c. Explicitly, a cone consists of, for each object j\in J, a morphism c\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} Dj, so that for each morphism j\xrightarrow {f}k\in J, the following diagram commutes:
The components \lambda _j of the cone are called its legs.
A limit of a diagram is a universal cone.

By the definition of universal elements, a limit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{lim} D\in C and a cone \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(-, \operatorname *{lim} D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D.
Dually:
A colimit of a diagram is a universal cocone.

By the definition of universal elements, a colimit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{colim} D\in C and a cocone D \xrightarrow {\lambda } \operatorname *{colim} D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} D, -)\cong \operatorname *{Cocone}_D.

fr:title.text: Map out of colimits, map into limits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Map out of colimits, map into limits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The universal property of limits makes it easy to construct morphisms into them; the universal property of colimits makes it easy to construct maps out of them.
A product is a limit of a discrete diagram. Its legs are called projections.
A coproduct is a colimit of a discrete diagram. Its colegs are called coprojections.
A pullback is a limit of a diagram of shape \bullet \to \bullet \leftarrow \bullet .
The symbol \lrcorner in the previous diagram denotes that the square is a pullback.
A pushout is a colimit of a diagram of shape \bullet \leftarrow \bullet \to \bullet .
The symbol \ulcorner in the previous diagram denotes that the square is a pushout.
An terminal object is a limit of an empty diagram.
By the universal property of limits, an object t is terminal in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism c\to t.
An initial object is a colimit of an empty diagram.
By the universal property of colimits, an object i is initial in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism i\to c.
An equalizer is a limit of a diagram of shape \bullet \rightrightarrows \bullet .
A coequalizer is a colimit of a diagram of shape \bullet \rightrightarrows \bullet .

fr:title.text: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism of cones. Explicitly, let J\xrightarrow {d} C be a diagram and suppose x\xrightarrow {\lambda } D and y\xrightarrow {\mu } D are both limiting cones. Then there is a unique isomorphism x\to y commuting with the \lambda and \mu .
Dually, colimits are unique up to unique isomorphism of cocones.

This follows from the characterization of representable isomorphism, but we give a direct proof. To show isomorphism, note that the universal property of limits induces a pair of unique maps x\xtofrom [g]{f} y commuting with the cones; it remains to show these are isomorphisms. The composite gf is a map x\to x commuting with the cone \lambda , but 1_x is another such map, so by uniqueness of suchs maps gf = 1_x. The same works on the other side.
Let J\xrightarrow {F,G} C be naturally isomorphic diagrams. Then if their limits exist, they are isomorphic.
Taking limits is functorial and functors preserve isomorphism.
Let J be an index category and let C be J-complete. Then there is a functor C^J \xrightarrow {\operatorname *{lim}_J} C which acts on functors by taking the limit.
Note that this theorem relies on a choice of witnesses to the completeness of C, i.e. a canonical choice of limit of each J-shaped diagram.

Let I\times J\xrightarrow {F} C be a bifunctorial diagram such that the limits \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F and \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I F exist. Then \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} F exists, and the three limits are isomorphic.

Since representable isomorphism implies isomorphism, it suffices to prove that C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F) \cong C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} F) \cong C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I F) naturally in X. Since hom functors preserve limits, the desired result becomes \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J C(X, F) \cong \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} C(X, F) \cong \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I C(X, F); i.e., the general case reduces to that of Set. By the isomorphism I\times J\cong J\times I, it suffices to prove the first isomorphism.

The proof is essentially by currying. Let I\times J\xrightarrow {G} Set be a diagram. By the construction of limits in Set, the limit \operatorname *{lim}_J G(i, -) is the set of cones over G(i, -) with summit *, hence equivalently the set of J-tuples (x_j\in G(i, j)) satisfying G(i, f)(x_j) = x_{j'} for each j\xrightarrow {f}j'\in J. Taking the limit over I, we now conclude that \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J G consists of the tuples (x_{ij}\in G(i, j)) which commute with G-images of maps in I and J. This is exactly the data of \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} G.

Let I\times J\xrightarrow {F} C be a bifunctorial diagram such that the following limits and colimits exist. Then there is a canonical map \operatorname *{colim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F\to \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{colim}_I F.
In particular, the map goes from a colimit to a limit because colimits are easy to map out of, while limits are easy to map into.

fr:title.text: Limits and colimits in functor categories are computed pointwise

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits and colimits in functor categories are computed pointwise

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a small category. Then where \operatorname *{obj} C is the discrete category of objects, the forgetful functor C^A\to C^{\operatorname *{obj} A} strictly creates all limits and colimits in C. For each a\in A, the evaluation at a functor C^A\to C preserves all limits and colimits which exist in C.

We prove the result for limits and conclude for colimits by duality. For any diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C, the definition of \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta c, D) is the set of natural transformations c\to D, which by definition is the set of cones \operatorname *{Cone}_D(c). A right adjoint \operatorname *{lim}_J to this functor is thus characterized by the natural isomorphism \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta c, D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D(c)\cong C(c, \operatorname *{lim}_J D), which is the definition of the limit. Thus pointwise the right adjoint and the limit agree, and so the right adjoint extends uniquely to the limit functor.

Let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a diagram in a locally small category C whose limit exists. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(x, \operatorname *{lim} F)\cong \operatorname *{lim} C(x, F-), where the latter is a limit in Set.
Dually, let the colimit of F exist. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} F, x)\cong \operatorname *{lim}_{J^\text {op}} C(F-, x).

Let C be locally small. The hom bifunctor preserves limits in both arguments. In particular, covariant hom-functors preserve limits and contravariant hom-functors preserve colimits, and so representable functors preserve limits.

We show the result for covariant hom-functors. Let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a diagram in C with limit \operatorname *{lim} F\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} Fj. The image of this diagram under C(x, -) is the diagram J\xrightarrow {F} C\xrightarrow {C(x, -)} Set, which is a limit in Set by the representability of limits.

fr:title.text: Yoneda embedding preserves and reflects limits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Yoneda embedding preserves and reflects limits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Yoneda embedding preserves and reflects limits.
Preservation of limits follows because hom-functors preserve limits and limits in functor categories are computed pointwise.
Reflection of limits follows because the Yoneda embedding is fully faithful and fully faithful functors reflect limits.
A category is complete if it has all small limits.
A category is cocomplete if it has all small colimits.
A category is complete if and only if it has all small products and equalizers.
Dually, a category is cocomplete if and only if it has all small coproducts and coequalizers.
The forwards direction is immediate, because products and equalizers are limits.
In the backwards direction, let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a small diagram. Now we define maps c and d using the universal property of the product as follows:

To demonstrate the universal property of the limit, let z\xrightarrow {\mu } F be another cone over F. Then the legs of the cone yield a map z\to \prod _{j\in J} Fj by the universal property of the product. Since it is a cone, hence commutes with Ff, this map equalizes the previous diagram. We obtain the desired result by the universal property of the equalizer.
Set is complete.

By the completeness criterion, it suffices to give products and equalizers. Products are given by the cartesian product. The equalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows }B is \{a\in A: f(a) = b(a)\}.

Let J\xrightarrow {D} Set be a small diagram. We define \operatorname *{lim} D = \operatorname *{Cone}_D(*) = \operatorname {Hom}(*, D), where * is the constant functor at the singleton and \operatorname *{Cone} is the cone functor. Note that this is indeed a set, because J is small. An element of this set is a natural transformation *\xrightarrow {\mu } D, which consists of a morphism *\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Dj for each j\in J, hence canonically identifies a J-tuple of elements (x_i\in Dj). The legs of should be maps \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } Dj; we define these by (*\xrightarrow {\mu } D)\xmapsto {\lambda _j} \mu _j(*).

To show that this cone is limiting, let Z\xrightarrow {
u } D be a cone. We need to show that 
u factors uniquely through \lambda . An element z\in Z identifies a map *	o Z, and hence a cone *	o Z\xrightarrow {
u } D, which is thus an element t(z)\in \operatorname *{lim} D. Now \lambda _j(t(z)) = (
u z)_j = 
u _j(z), and so 
u = \lambda t, as desired. It remains to show uniqueness, but any function Z\xrightarrow {u} \operatorname *{lim} D factoring 
u must satisfy u(z)_j = \lambda _j(u(z)) = 
u _j(z) = (
u z)_j = t(z)_j, so we are done.
Set is cocomplete.

By the cocompleteness criterion, it suffices to give coproducts and coequalizers. Coproducts are given by the disjoint union. The coequalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } B is B / \sim , where \sim is the equivalence relation generated by f(a) \sim g(a) for all a \in A, and / denotes the quotient of sets.
An adjunction F \dashv G between categories C and D entails the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a pair of functors F:C\leftrightarrows D:G, called the left and right adjoints;
a family of natural bijections D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd), called transposition;
a natural transformation 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } GF, called the unit;
a natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D, called the counit.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data relates as follows:

fr:ul.fr:li: the component c\xrightarrow {\eta _c}GFc of the unit is the transpose of the identity 1_{Fc};
the component FGd\xrightarrow {\epsilon _d}d of the counit is the transpose of the identity 1_{Gd};
the transposition of a map Fc\xrightarrow {f} d is the composite c\xrightarrow {\eta _c} GFc\xrightarrow {Gf} Gd;
the transposition of a map c\xrightarrow {g} Gd is the composite Fc\xrightarrow {Fg} FGd\xrightarrow {\epsilon _d} d;

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F: C\leftrightarrows D: G be a pair of opposing functors. Then the following are equivalent specifications of an adjunction:

fr:ul.fr:li: there exists a natural bijection D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd);
there exists a pair of natural transformations 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } GF and FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D satisfying the triangle identities;

there exists a natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D so that the formula for adjoint maps induces an isomorphism (-)^\sharp = C(c, Gd)\xrightarrow {F} D(Fc, FGd)\xrightarrow {(\epsilon _d)_*} D(Fc, d).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first implies the second via the triangle identities of the unit and counit.

fr:ul.fr:li: H\eta = \eta 'H, where \eta and \eta ' are the units of the adjunctions;
K\epsilon = \epsilon 'K, where \epsilon and \epsilon ' are the counits of the adjunctions;
transposition commutes with H and K.

fr:title.text: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the forwards direction, suppose that the isomorphisms are natural, and further that the left-hand square commutes; the case in which the right-hand square commutes is similar. By the naturality of the isomorphism in C, the transpose of kf^\sharp is (Gk) f^\flat , while by naturality in D, the transpose of (Fh)g^\sharp is hg^\flat . Since the maps are equal, their transposes must also be equal; this is commutativity of the square on the right.

fr:title.text: Adjoints are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Adjoints are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F and F' be left adjoints to G. Then there is a unique natural isomorphism \theta : F\cong F' commuting with the units and counits of the adjunctions.
Dually, right adjoints are also unique up to unique isomorphism commuting with the units and counits.
To show uniqueness, note that \theta _c is uniquely specified as the transpose of \eta '_c across the adjunction F\dashv G, but this relationship is required for commutativity with the units to hold.
There are composite bijections of hom-sets E(F'Fc, e)\cong D(Fc, G'E)\cong C(c, GG'e).

Let \eta and \epsilon be the unit and counits of the adjunction F\dashv G. We give a unit \eta ' and counit \epsilon ' witnessing the adjunction F_*\dashv G_*. Given a functor J\xrightarrow {H} C, the component H\xrightarrow {\eta '_H} GFH is the whiskered natural transformation \eta H. Given a functor J\xrightarrow {K} D, the component FGK\xrightarrow {\epsilon '_K} K is similarly \epsilon K.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a functor so that, for each object d\in D, there exists a cofree object Gd\in C, i.e. an object Gd\in C together with an isomorphism {D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd)} natural in D. Then there exists a unique extension of this assignment into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C, which is then necessarily right adjoint to F.
Dually, suppose that for each d\in D, there exists a free object Fd\in C. Then this data extends uniquely into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C which is necessarily left adjoint to F.

fr:title.text: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:title.text: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Right adjoints preserve limits. Dually, left adjoints preserve colimits.

Letting \Delta be the constant diagram functor, we have the following series of natural isomorphisms: \begin {aligned} C^J(\Delta c, GK) &\cong D^J(F\Delta c, K) &&\text {by (1)}\\\\ &\cong D^J(\Delta Fc, K) &&\text {by (2)}\\\\ &\cong D(Fc, \operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the definition of limits}\\\\ &\cong C(c, G\operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the adjunction}. \end {aligned} By definition of limits, this exhibits G\operatorname *{lim}_J K as a limit of GK.

Let D\xrightarrow {G} C be a continuous functor with locally small complete domain D. Suppose that D satisfies the solution set condition: for each object c in C, there exists a small family of maps c\xrightarrow {f_i} Gd_i in C such that any map c\xrightarrow {f} Gd factors through one of the f_i via the G-image of a map d_i\to d in D. Then G admits a left adjoint.

Let D\xrightarrow {G} C be a continuous functor with complete domain and locally small domain and codomain. Suppose that D has a small coseparating family and that every collection of subobjects x_\alpha \hookrightarrow x in D admits a meet, i.e. a limit. Then G has a left adjoint.
The discrete topology on a set X is the topology consisting of all subsets of X; this forms a functor Set\to Top which is left adjoint to the forgetful functor.
The indiscrete or trivial topology on a set X is the topology consisting of just X and the empty set; this forms a functor Set\to Top which is right adjoint to the forgetful functor.

An explicit construction is as follows: given a set A, we let \mathcal {F} A be the set of finitely supported formal \mathbb {Z}-linear combinations \sum _{a\in A} c_a a in A, with pointwise addition.
By the general adjoint functor theorem, the forgetful functor Grp \xrightarrow {U} Set admits a left adjoint, called the free group functor.

The forgetful functor creates limits, by a straightforward diagram chase. Moreover, for any set x, a solution set consists of (the isomorphism classes of) those groups with sufficiently small cardinalities so that they may be generated by the image of x into some UG. Indeed, because x has some fixed cardinality, this set is (essentially) small.

fr:title.text: Homotopy category of an infinity category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Homotopy category of an infinity category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By abstract nonsense, the nerve functor has a left adjoint, called one-truncation or the homotopy category, and written \tau _1 or h. In particular, it sends a quasicategory C to the category whose objects come from the quasicategory and whose morphisms are equivalence classes of morphisms in the quasicategory.

The singular simplicial complex functor from spaces to simplicial sets is the right adjoint to the geometric realization functor. By abstract nonsense, this is given by \operatorname {Sing}(X)_n = \operatorname {Top}(|\Delta ^n|, X).

It remains to show the desired adjunction. Since 1_y is terminal in C/y, a map n\to \Pi _f m in C/y induces, again by the universal property of the pullback, a unique map n\to \left [c\xrightarrow {m} x\xrightarrow {f} y^{(x\xrightarrow {f} y)}\right ] whose post-composition with m is the identity 1_f. Taking the transpose yields a map \left [f\times n\right ]\xrightarrow {g^\dag } \left [c\xrightarrow {m}x\xrightarrow {f} y\right ]. However, the product in C/y is exactly the pullback in C, so that (since mg = 1_x), this is equivalently a map f^*n\to m in C/x.
For any category C, the category of presheaves \hat {C} is cartesian closed.

Products are computed pointwise, hence inherited from Set. By the Yoneda lemma, for c\in C an exponential Q^P, if it exists, should satisfy Q^P c \cong \hat {C}(yc, Q^P)\cong \hat {C}(yc\times P, Q). Taking this to define Q^P, we now show the desired adjunction.

Fixing some P and Q suffices to construct the evaluation natural transformation Q^P\times P\xrightarrow {\operatorname {ev}} Q (itself the Q-component of a natural transformation (-)^P\times P\to P) which induces an isomorphism on adjoint hom-sets. At c\in C, the component \operatorname {ev}_c is given a natural transformation yc\times P\xrightarrow {\phi } Q and an element p\in Pc; we define \operatorname {ev}_c(\phi , p) = \phi _c(1_c, p).

Now, it remains to show that there is a bijection \hat {C}(R, Q^P)\xrightarrow {-\times P} \hat {C}(R\times P, Q^P\times P)\xrightarrow {\operatorname {ev}_*} \hat {C}(R\times P, Q). That is, given a natural transformation R\times P\xrightarrow {\alpha } Q, we must show that there is a unique natural transformation R\xrightarrow {\beta } Q^P mapping to \alpha . At c\in C, this is a set-function Rc\xrightarrow {\beta _c} Q^Pc, where the latter is the set \hat {C}(yc\times P, Q). As such, for each element r\in Rc, we must define a natural transformation yc\times P\xrightarrow {\beta _c(r)} Q.

A closed monoidal category is a symmetric monoidal category C such that the bifunctor \otimes is closed. Explicitly, this means there is a bifunctor C^\text {op}\times C\xrightarrow {[-, -]} C, called the internal hom, together with a natural isormorphism C(x\otimes y, z)\cong C(x, [y, z]), called currying.
The counit of the adjunction (-\otimes y)\dashv [y, -] is called evaluation: it is a natural transformation [y, x]\otimes y\xrightarrow {\operatorname {ev}} x.

Applying the adjunction with x the monoidal unit I implies that maps y\to z are in natural bijection with maps I\to [y, z]. By the philosophy of generalized elements, this explains the name internal hom: its elements are maps.

Let D\xrightarrow {U} C be a functor and c\in C an object. Then a U-free object on c represents the functor C(c, U-). Explicitly, it is an object d\in D equipped with a bijection C(c, Uz)\cong D(d, z) natural in z\in D. In other words, it satisfies the universal property that Fc would have, for a left adjoint F to U.

Dually, a U-cofree object on c represents the functor C(U-, c). Explicitly, it is an object d\in D equipped with a bijection C(Uz, c)\cong D(z, d) natural in z\in D: it satisfies the universal property that Fc would have, for a right adjoint F to U.

Let C\xrightarrow {K} D be a functor and E a category. Suppose that, for each C\xrightarrow {F} E, the left Kan extension D\xrightarrow {\operatorname *{Lan}_K} F exists. Then this data extends uniquely into a functor E^C \xrightarrow {\operatorname *{Lan}_K} E^D that is left adjoint to the precomposition functor E^D \xrightarrow {K^*} E^C.
Dually, if the right Kan extensions \operatorname *{Ran}_K F all exist, this extends into a right adjoint to K^*.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By definition, Kan extensions are (co)free, and (co)free assignments extend uniquely to adjunctions.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A full subcategory D\hookrightarrow C is reflective if the inclusion admits a left adjoint, called the reflector.

An adjunction is monadic if the comparison functor to the Eilenberg-Moore category is an equivalence of categories. A functor D\xrightarrow {G} C is monadic if it is the left adjoint in a monadic adjunction; in this case D is monadic over C.
Let T be a monad on a category C. A resolution of T is an adjunction which induces T.

We prove the result for limits and conclude for colimits by duality. For any diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C, the definition of \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta c, D) is the set of natural transformations c\to D, which by definition is the set of cones \operatorname *{Cone}_D(c). A right adjoint \operatorname *{lim}_J to this functor is thus characterized by the natural isomorphism \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta c, D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D(c)\cong C(c, \operatorname *{lim}_J D), which is the definition of the limit. Thus pointwise the right adjoint and the limit agree, and so the right adjoint extends uniquely to the limit functor.

fr:title.text: Unit and counit of an adjunction

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Unit and counit of an adjunction

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Dually, the natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D whose component at d is the transpose of 1_{Gd} is called the counit of the adjunction.

An adjunction F\dashv G consists of a pair of opposing functors F: C\leftrightarrows D: G and a natural isomorphism D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd), called transposition. We say F is left adjoint to G and G is right adjoint to F, and write

When an adjunction is fixed, two maps f\in C and g\in D are adjoint or transposes if they are connected by the adjunction. We sometimes write Fc\xrightarrow {f^\sharp } d and c\xrightarrow {f^\flat } Gd for a pair of adjoint maps.
A bijection is an isomorphism in Set. Explicitly, a map is bijective if it is both injective and surjective.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D between categories C and D consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, an object Fx\in D;
for each morphism f\in C(x, y), a morphism Ff\in D(Fx, Fy).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must preserve the structure of the category, namely identities and composites, meaning:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, F1_x = 1_{Fx};
for each pair x\xrightarrow {f}y\xrightarrow {g}z in C, F(gf) = (Fg)(Fg).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A natural transformation F\xrightarrow {\alpha } G between functors C\xrightarrow {F,G} D consists of, for every object x\in C, a morphism \alpha _x: Fx\to Gx (the components) such that, for every morphism x\xrightarrow {f}y in C, the following diagram commutes:
A natural isomorphism is an isomorphism in a functor category. Explicitly, it is a natural transformation whose components are each isomorphisms.

Let F\xrightarrow {\alpha } G and G\xrightarrow {\beta } H be natural transformations with components \alpha _x and \beta _x, respectively. Then their vertical composite F\xrightarrow {\beta \alpha } H is the natural transformation with components (\beta \alpha )_x = \beta _x\alpha _x. Diagramatically:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzcd}[baseline=(current bounding box.center)] & \Downarrow \alpha \\[-2.1em] C\ar [rr, "F", bend left=50]\ar [rr, "G", near start]\ar [rr, "H"', bend right=50] && D & \rightsquigarrow & C \ar [rr, "F", bend left=50]\ar [rr, "H"', bend right=50] & \Downarrow \beta \alpha & D\makebox [0pt][l]{.} \\[-2.1em] & \Downarrow \beta \end {tikzcd}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
